articles.headline: Some States See Budgets at Risk as Oil Price Falls
articles.snippet: A study projected that job losses tied to the decline in energy costs would be largest in Wyoming, Oklahoma and North Dakota.
articles.abstract: A study projected that job losses tied to the decline in energy costs would be largest in Wyoming, Oklahoma and North Dakota.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — States dependent on oil and gas revenue are bracing for layoffs, slashing agency budgets and growing increasingly anxious about the ripple effect that falling oil prices may have on their local economies.
articles.byline: By Manny Fernandez and Jeremy Alford

articles.headline: Finding Communities That Connect and Nurture the Like-Minded
articles.snippet: Retirees are flocking to join fellow artists, letter carriers, R.V. enthusiasts and more in places where they can stay active while getting needed care.
articles.abstract: Retirees are flocking to join fellow artists, letter carriers, R.V. enthusiasts and more in places where they can stay active while getting needed care.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jon Allen lived most of his life very much out of the closet. He didn’t want to go back in when he grew older.

articles.headline: Adidos and Hotwind? In China, Brands Adopt Names to Project Foreign Flair
articles.snippet: Chinese retailers, trying to appeal to shoppers who prefer goods made overseas, choose brand names that sound foreign, even if they don’t make sense in a foreign language.
articles.abstract: Chinese retailers, trying to appeal to shoppers who prefer goods made overseas, choose brand names that sound foreign, even if they don’t make sense in a foreign language.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Chrisdien Deny, a retail chain with more than 500 locations across China, sells belts, shoes and clothing with an “Italian style” — and a logo with a font similar to Christian Dior’s.

articles.headline: After Scrutiny, C.I.A. Mandate Is Untouched
articles.snippet: Four decades ago, a Senate committee’s revelations about abuses committed by the intelligence community led to major alterations at the C.I.A. But times have changed.
articles.abstract: Four decades ago, a Senate committee’s revelations about abuses committed by the intelligence community led to major alterations at the C.I.A. But times have changed.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Over a lunch in Washington in 1976, James J. Angleton, for years the ruthless chief of counterintelligence at the C.I.A., likened the agency to a medieval city occupied by an invading army.

articles.headline: A Flurry of Varying Cellphone Offers Sows Confusion Among Consumers
articles.snippet: Even executives at the wireless phone companies say their industry has created a confounding abundance of competing plans.
articles.abstract: Even executives at the wireless phone companies say their industry has created a confounding abundance of competing plans.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — One wireless phone plan allows customers to upgrade to a new phone in less than two years. Another allows a pool of data to be shared across multiple devices. Yet another offers unlimited data, but only at slower Internet speeds. All these perks are there for the taking, yet the average wireless phone bill continues with its monthly sting.

articles.headline: Risks in Using Social Media to Spot Signs of Mental Distress
articles.snippet: The ill-fated introduction in Britain of an app to detect predictors of suicide shows what may happen when social media posts are scrutinized for cues about a person’s mental health.
articles.abstract: The ill-fated introduction in Britain of an app to detect predictors of suicide shows what may happen when social media posts are scrutinized for cues about a person’s mental health.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Samaritans, a well-known suicide-prevention group in Britain, recently introduced a free web app that would alert users whenever someone they followed on Twitter posted worrisome phrases like “tired of being alone” or “hate myself.”

articles.headline: Sudden U.S. Thaw Worries Cuban Dissidents
articles.snippet: As the United States and Cuba enter a period of unprecedented dialogue, many dissidents who stood with American officials in condemning the Castros contend that President Obama gave away too much.
articles.abstract: As the United States and Cuba enter a period of unprecedented dialogue, many dissidents who stood with American officials in condemning the Castros contend that President Obama gave away too much.
articles.lead_paragraph: HAVANA — Sitting in her brother’s spare apartment, near a blinking plastic Christmas tree, Sonia Garro was relishing her newfound freedom, happily trading her prison garb for a purple dress and flip-flops with bright pink plastic bows over the toes.
articles.byline: By Victoria Burnett and William Neuman

articles.headline: Even Loyalty No Guarantee Against Putin
articles.snippet: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, who wields virtually unchallenged power to reward a new class of oligarchs, also uses the same instrument to punish those who oppose him.
articles.abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, who wields virtually unchallenged power to reward a new class of oligarchs, also uses the same instrument to punish those who oppose him.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Vladimir P. Yevtushenkov, not long ago one of Russia’s richest men, walked free on Dec. 17 after 92 days under house arrest. He was held by prosecutors on charges of laundering money from the purchase of an oil company in 2009 — charges that President Vladimir V. Putin ultimately acknowledged could not be substantiated.
articles.byline: By Steven Lee Myers and Jo Becker

articles.headline: Entering the Secret Garden of Private Equity
articles.snippet: It’s a rare shift in a long-opaque industry: A firm is letting investors hire an outside monitor to review a fund’s books and practices.
articles.abstract: It’s a rare shift in a long-opaque industry: A firm is letting investors hire an outside monitor to review a fund’s books and practices.
articles.lead_paragraph: Is private equity about to get a little less private?

articles.headline: How Dreams and Money Didn’t Mix at a Texas Distillery
articles.snippet: The founder of Balcones, an award-winning artisanal distillery in Waco, Tex., sought out capital to expand. But his passion collided with investors’ bottom line.
articles.abstract: The founder of Balcones, an award-winning artisanal distillery in Waco, Tex., sought out capital to expand. But his passion collided with investors’ bottom line.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was February 2013, and Chip Tate, the 39-year-old founder and president of Balcones, one of the country’s most successful artisanal distilleries, was desperate for money.

articles.headline: Amazon Offers All-You-Can-Eat Books. Authors Turn Up Noses.
articles.snippet: Some self-published writers say their income has seen a large and rapid decrease under Amazon’s Kindle Unlimited program, and argue that the system is unfair.
articles.abstract: Some self-published writers say their income has seen a large and rapid decrease under Amazon’s Kindle Unlimited program, and argue that the system is unfair.
articles.lead_paragraph: Authors are upset with Amazon. Again.

articles.headline: In Limbo, a City in China Faces Life After Graft
articles.snippet: The town of Lüliang in Shanxi Province, whose coal helped fuel China’s economic boom, is at the center of a crackdown that challenges the close ties between business and government.
articles.abstract: The town of Lüliang in Shanxi Province, whose coal helped fuel China’s economic boom, is at the center of a crackdown that challenges the close ties between business and government.
articles.lead_paragraph: LÜLIANG, China — For 10 fat years, this mountainous corner of central China was synonymous with the nation’s energy-hungry economic takeoff. Its rich deposits of coal fueled the most frenetic era of the Chinese boom, turning owners of small mines into millionaires and dirty towns into gleaming cities.

articles.headline: The Cost of the U.S. Ban on Paying for Hostages
articles.snippet: Former hostages and Syrian rebel commanders say that they offered information they believed could help free American captives, but that officials seemed uninterested.
articles.abstract: Former hostages and Syrian rebel commanders say that they offered information they believed could help free American captives, but that officials seemed uninterested.
articles.lead_paragraph: GAZIANTEP, Turkey — For a fleeting moment last year, Louai Abo Aljoud, a Syrian journalist, made eye contact with the American hostages being held by the Islamic State militant group.

articles.headline: Indonesian Agency Says Missing AirAsia Jet Probably Sank
articles.snippet: The head of the agency searching for Flight 8501 said that he believed the aircraft was “at the bottom of the sea” and warned that the country lacked adequate equipment for an underwater search.
articles.abstract: The head of the agency searching for Flight 8501 said that he believed the aircraft was “at the bottom of the sea” and warned that the country lacked adequate equipment for an underwater search.
articles.lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — The head of the Indonesian agency searching for a missing AirAsia jet carrying 162 people said Monday that he believed the aircraft was “at the bottom of the sea” and warned that the country lacked adequate equipment to conduct an underwater search.

articles.headline: Pinterest Pushing Deeper Into Ads
articles.snippet: On New Year’s Day, the digital scrapbook Pinterest will start selling ads to marketers, competing with Google, Twitter and Facebook for ad revenue from the biggest consumer brands.
articles.abstract: On New Year’s Day, the digital scrapbook Pinterest will start selling ads to marketers, competing with Google, Twitter and Facebook for ad revenue from the biggest consumer brands.
articles.lead_paragraph: A quick glance at the digital scrapbook Pinterest makes it seem like the anti-Facebook. It has no stream filled with friends’ faces and baby pictures, but rather a sprawling, colorful grid of recipes, photographs of clothes and a shopping list of presents to buy for loved ones.

articles.headline: ‘Monster Strike’ Gives Former Social Media Giant Mixi a Second Act
articles.snippet: Mixi was a once-dominant social network that Facebook had driven to the edge of collapse — and then it created the mobile game Monster Strike.
articles.abstract: Mixi was a once-dominant social network that Facebook had driven to the edge of collapse — and then it created the mobile game Monster Strike.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — It was a familiar trajectory for a social network like Facebook that did not happen to be Facebook: One moment there were tens of millions of users and a multibillion-dollar stock market valuation. The next, a plunge toward whatever-happened-to-it oblivion.

articles.headline: Behind the Scenes of ‘Today,’ ‘This Morning’ and ‘Good Morning America’
articles.snippet: In the dark hours of the morning, some of television’s biggest celebrities are already rolling out into the streets of the city that never sleeps.
articles.abstract: In the dark hours of the morning, some of television’s biggest celebrities are already rolling out into the streets of the city that never sleeps.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the dark hours of the morning, some of television’s biggest celebrities are already rolling out into the streets of the city that never sleeps.

articles.headline: Pot Pie, Redefined? Chefs Start to Experiment With Cannabis
articles.snippet: As states legalize marijuana, cooking with cannabis is emerging as a legitimate and very lucrative culinary pursuit.
articles.abstract: As states legalize marijuana, cooking with cannabis is emerging as a legitimate and very lucrative culinary pursuit.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOULDER, Colo. — Recreational marijuana is both illegal and controversial in most of the country, and its relationship to food does not rise much above a joke about brownies or a stoner chef’s late-night pork belly poutine.

articles.headline: In Battle to Defang ISIS, U.S. Targets Its Psychology
articles.snippet: Officials acknowledge they have barely made a dent in the larger, longer-term campaign to kill the ideology that animates the terrorist movement.
articles.abstract: Officials acknowledge they have barely made a dent in the larger, longer-term campaign to kill the ideology that animates the terrorist movement.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Maj. Gen. Michael K. Nagata, commander of American Special Operations forces in the Middle East, sought help this summer in solving an urgent problem for the American military: What makes the Islamic State so dangerous?

articles.headline: Media Companies (and Executives) on the Hot Seat in 2015
articles.snippet: Taking stock of the businesses that face challenges in the coming year.
articles.abstract: Taking stock of the businesses that face challenges in the coming year.
articles.lead_paragraph: While it’s great news that the economy is (slowly) coming back, it’s important to remember that a rising tide does not necessarily lift all boats. That is especially true in the media industry, where a bad stretch of advertising and extensive challenges to existing business models have clobbered many legacy outfits.

articles.headline: In North Dakota, a Tale of Oil, Corruption and Death
articles.snippet: Tex G. Hall, a tribal chief connected to the oil industry, has pushed profits on the Fort Berthold Reservation. But accusations of corruption and murder for hire have upended business as usual.
articles.abstract: Tex G. Hall, a tribal chief connected to the oil industry, has pushed profits on the Fort Berthold Reservation. But accusations of corruption and murder for hire have upended business as usual.
articles.lead_paragraph: FORT BERTHOLD INDIAN RESERVATION, N.D. — Tex G. Hall, the three-term tribal chairman on this remote, once impoverished reservation, was the very picture of confidence as he strode to the lectern at his third Annual Bakken Oil and Gas Expo and gazed out over a stuffed, backlit mountain lion.
articles.byline: By Deborah Sontag and Brent McDonald

articles.headline: China Adds New Barrier to Gmail
articles.snippet: The government appears to have blocked the ability of people in China to access their Gmail accounts through third-party email clients.
articles.abstract: The government appears to have blocked the ability of people in China to access their Gmail accounts through third-party email clients.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The Chinese government appears to have blocked the ability of people in China to gain access to Google’s email service through third-party email services like Apple Mail or Microsoft Outlook, which many Chinese and foreigners had been relying on to use their Gmail accounts after an earlier blocking effort by officials, according to Internet analysts and users in China.
articles.byline: By Edward Wong, Kiki Zhao and Conor Dougherty
